children.name: not by any mode or transport
walk a1
children.definition: walk/wɔːk/
examples: đi bộ
▪ anna missed the bus, so she decided to walk.

children.name: on foot a2
children.definition: on foot/ɒn ˈfʊt/  if you go somewhereon foot,you walk instead of going by car, bus, train etc :
examples: ▪ it’s not far. it’ll take you about ten minutes on foot.
go on foot : đi bộ
▪ the bus left us at the bottom of the hill, and we went the rest of the way on foot.
on foot /ɒn ˈfʊt/ [adverb] if you go somewhere on foot, you walk there:
đi bộ , bằng cách đi bộ
▪ the two men had attempted to cross the mountains on foot.
on foot đi bộ
walking
_are you going by bicycle or on foot?

children.name: wanderlust x
children.definition: wanderlustwrittena strong desire to travel and to experience life in other countries:đi du lịch
examples: it was not wanderlust alone that made him keen to visit brazil. he thought he might hear news of his natural mother there.
in july wanderlust takes over the whole nation.

children.name: itchy feet x
children.definition: itchy feet britishinformalthe desire to travel, which makes it difficult for you to stay in one place for very long :ngứa chân ( muốn đi đây đi đó )
examples: get itchy feetto start to want to travel or do something different
i always get itchy feet at this time of year, in the spring.
after three years in the job she began to get itchy feet.

children.name: travel b1
children.definition: travel the activity of travelling : đi chuyển , đi lại
examples: the new job involves a fair amount of travel.
air travelthere has been a major increase in air travel during the last twenty years.
rail travelthe measures were introduced to make rail travel safer.
bus/coach/car etc travelthe price is £98, inclusive of coach travel.
foreign/international/overseas travelthe job offers opportunities for foreign travel.
long-distance travellong-distance travel is becoming much more common these days.
business travelbusiness travel often took him away from his family.
space travellarge rockets are used for space travel and exploration.
the travel industrythe storms have had a huge effect on the country's travel industry.
travel arrangementsi still have to make all the travel arrangements.
travel expenses/coststhey offered to pay my travel expenses.
travel insuranceyou are strongly advised to take out travel insurance.
a travel book/guidekyushu looks so lovely in the travel books.
a travel writeran award-winning travel writer
a form/mode/method/means of traveli find the train a more comfortable mode of travel.
common errors
►do not use 'a travel' to meana journeyora trip, for example by saying 'a long/short travel'. saya long/short journeyora long/short trip.

children.name: to travel as part of your job
travel a1
children.definition: travelđi lại ( vì công việc )
examples: ▪ do you have to travel a lot in your new job?
▪ the post will involve you travelling to germany about three times a year.
travellingbritish /travelingamerican [uncountable noun]
▪ the job involves a certain amount of travelling.

children.name: tour b1
children.definition: tour if a sports team, entertainer, politician etc tours, they travel to many different places in order toplay,perform,or be seen:đi lưu diễn
examples: haynes recorded with charlie parker and toured with sarah vaughan in the 1950s.
the theatre company will tour later this year.
tour the country/the us/russia etc
the team is currently touring australia in a series of friendly games.

children.name: be on tour a2
children.definition: be on tour/biː ɒn ˈtʊəʳ/  if a musician, actor, sportsman etc is on tour, he or she is travelling to many different places so that people can see them play or perform:đang lưu diễn
examples: ▪ jennings is currently on tour, promoting and reading from his new children’s book.
▪ at the moment the band is on tour in europe.

children.name: en route x
children.definition: en route on the way to somewhere:trên đường
examples: we stopped en route to meet some friends in brussels.
en route from/to
a flight en route from tokyo to sydney
the flight was en route from tokyo to sydney when it experienced engine trouble.
en route forbritish english:
we stayed there en route for london.
why don’t we stop for lunch en route?

children.name: be on the move x
children.definition: be on the move informal to travel from one place to another, especially because it isdifficultorimpossiblefor you to stay where you were:đi lại, đi chuyển,
examples: he was always on the move, never staying in one town more than a few days.
the guerrillas stay on the move to avoid capture.
thousands of refugees are on the move, fleeing heavy shelling in their home towns.
we're going to be on the move all next week, but we'll call you when we get to edinburgh.

children.name: to travel to a lot of different places
travel around a1
children.definition: travel around/ travel rounduk  to travel toa lot ofdifferent places, especially when youdo not planexactly where you are going:
examples: ▪ david travelled around a lot in the ‘60s and ’70s.
travel around europe/the north/canada etc
▪ i’d love to have a job that let me travel around the world.
▪ she’s been traveling around the country trying to get big companies interested in her ideas.

children.name: tour b1
children.definition: tour uk to travel to a lot of different placeswithin a particular area or country, especially forpleasureandinterest:đi du lịch
examples: ▪ for our summer vacation this year we’re touring spain in a camper.
▪ we shall tour the city for two hours and then meet back at the bus.

children.name: do x
children.definition: do to travel to a lot of different placesin a particular area,especiallyas part of a holiday:đi du lịch ( quanh vùng nào )
examples: last year we did the greek islands but we were thinking of the usa this year.
there’s not a whole lot to see, so you can do the city in two or three days.

children.name: get around x
children.definition: get around/ get rounduk  to travel to alargenumberof places, usuallyin a short time:đi lại
examples: the metro system in mexico city is very good. it makes it really easy to get around.
get around london/europe/the midwest etc
you can use free shuttle buses to get around the city.

children.name: explore b1
children.definition: explore to travel to many different places in aparticulararea, because you are interestedto find outmore about them:khám phá
examples: ▪ we’ll be in istanbul for three days, so there will be plenty of time to explore.
▪ whenever possible, she and flynn would go off and explore the countryside, taking a picnic with them.

children.name: see the world u
children.definition: see the world to travel around to different places allover the worldso that you get the experience of living in other countries:
examples: after leaving college and earning some money he set off to see the world.

children.name: on your travels c1
children.definition: on your travels if youdosomethingon your travels, you do it while you are travelling to different places:khi đang đi du lịch
examples: ▪ i picked up a few words of chinese on my travels, but i don’t speak it fluently.
on your travels to
▪ corbett met a number of his contacts on his travels to taiwan.

children.name: go abroad b1
children.definition: go abroad to travel to another country, especially forpleasureandinterest:đi ngước ngoài
examples: ▪ here’s a list of things to think about before you go abroad.
▪ i’m the only person i know who’s never been abroad or even on a plane.
be abroad
▪ when their mother died she was unable to contact her brother because he was abroadsomewhere.

children.name: go overseas b2
children.definition: go overseas/ˌgəʊ əʊvəʳˈsiːz/  to travel to another country in orderto stay there for a long time, for example because you have been sent to work there:
examples: đi sang hải ngoại
▪ i wrote a letter to the interviewer, explaining that i was going overseas for six months.
▪ the soldiers underwent training for three months before the unit went overseas.

children.name: visit a1
children.definition: visit/ˈvɪzɪt, ˈvɪzət/  to travel to another countryfor a short time, especially because you want tofind out what it is like:
examples: đến thăm ( để biết về một nơi nào đó )
▪ he was the first traveller from the british isles to visit abyssinia.
▪ thousands of americans visit thailand each year.

children.name: go out to u
children.definition: go out to/ˌgəʊ ˈaʊt tuː/  british to travel to another country that is along wayaway:
examples: đi đến ( sang nước khác )
▪ he went out to west africa in 1962 and has been there ever since.
▪ the chief financial officer went out to korea to oversee the merger.

children.name: backpacking b1
children.definition: backpacking the activity of travellingindependentlyto a lot ofdifferentareas, carrying your clothes etc in a special bag on your back:du lịch bụi, đeo ba lô đi du lịch
examples: backpacking is especially popular among students and young people.
a backpacking trip
go backpacking
last year, he went backpacking in the us.

children.name: roll x
children.definition: roll if an aircraft or a ship rolls, it leans to one side and then to the other because of the wind or waves : tròng trành lộn vòng
examples: roll[u] the roll of a ship or aircraft is its movement from side to side in the water or air.

children.name: travelling x
children.definition: travellinguk /travelingus  moving from place to place in order to work, perform etc: du lịch
examples: 1 travelling expensesmoney that is used to pay for the cost of travelling while someone is on a trip for their company
2 travelling companionsomeone you are on a journey with
3 travelling musician/circus/exhibition etcsomeone or something that goes from place to place
the traveling show includes historical films as well as 300 genuine artifacts that kids can handle.
his father was a travelling salesman and was very rarely at home.
4 travelling rug/clock etcbritish englisha clock etc designed to be used when you are travelling
5 travelling people/folkbritish englishtravellers

children.name: to travel a particular distance or at a particular speed
go a1
children.definition: go
examples: go 40 miles/five kilometres etcto travel a particular distance, especially as onlypart of a journey:đi được ( bao nhiêu đoạn đường )
we had only gone about five miles when i started to feel sick.
how far have we gone today?
it took us over an hour to go ten miles.
go[i or t] a1 to move or travel in a particular way :
the car was going much too fast.
we went a different way from usual that day.

children.name: do x
children.definition: doespecially britishto travel aparticular distanceor to travel at aparticular speed
examples: my new car does 50 miles to the gallon/30 km to the litre (= uses one gallon of fuel to travel 50 miles, or one litre to travel 30 km) .
we were doing 150 (km an hour) along the motorway.
do 20 miles/30 kilometres etcto travel for 20 miles, 30 kilometres etc:đi được
we were riding through the hills, but we still managed to do 30 miles each day.
i bought the car for £3500, and it’s only done 30,000 miles!
it's an old car and it's done over 80 000 miles.

children.name: cover b2
children.definition: cover to travel a particular distance, especially alongdistance, that is part of alongerjourneyyou are making:đi được
examples: it took him three days to cover the distance from laingsbury to albertsville.
in one twenty-five day period, he covered 800 miles.
we covered 400km in three hours.
they were hoping to cover 40 miles yesterday.
a leopard cancovera lot ofgroundvery quickly.

children.name: travel b1
children.definition: travel to go a particular distance or at a particular speed
examples: supersonic planes can travel faster than the speed of sound.
travel at
the train was travelling at 100 mph.
they travelled 200 miles on the first day.

children.name: to travel from one place to another
travel a1
children.definition: travel to go from one place to another, or to several places, especially ones that are far away :
examples: someday i’d like totravel abroad.
travel to/across/through/around etc
we’re planning to travel across america this summer.
travel abroadonly the affluent could afford to take vacations or to travel abroad.
travel widely/extensivelyhe travelled extensively in europe studying geology.
travel light(= not take many things with you )the idea was to travel light, so travis allowed her to pack only one change of clothing.
travel by train/car/air etcemily hated travelling by train.
travel the world/countryto go to most parts of the world or of a particular country
they travelled the world together.

children.name: commute c1
children.definition: commute to regularly travel a long distance to work or school.
examples: she commutes to work by bicycle.
commute to/from/between
jim commutes to manhattan every day.
commuter[c] sb who lives in a different town, city etc from the one where they work, and who therefore travels a long distance every day to get to work:
it was a small shop that catered to commuters and local workers.
the train was packed with commuters.
commuter train/plane etc
each region has one organization controlling buses and operating its commuter trains.
commute[c usually s] informal a journey that sb makes each day to work, especially when they live a fairly long way away from their work:
the commute from kent into london can be horrendous.
a 1-hour/20-minute etc commute
i had no money, two small children, and a 90-minute commute to work each day.
it's at least an hour's commute to work.

children.name: go a1
children.definition: go to go somewhere – often used instead oftravel:
examples: we’re going to greece for our holidays this year.
he’s gone to london on business.
it’s quicker to go by plane.
go by bus/train/car etc
it’ll be quicker to go by train.
go and do sth(alsogo do somethingamerican english) [not in past tenses] to move to a particular place in order to do something :
go wash your hands.
i went and spoke to the manager.

children.name: cross a2
children.definition: cross to travel across a verylargeareasuch as a desert, an ocean, or an area of mountains:băng qua
examples: it took a lot of courage to cross the rocky mountains in those days.
they crossed the atlantic in a convoy of fifty ships.
the slaves crossed the atlantic in the holds of the ships.
crossing[c] c1 a short journey in aboatorshipfrom one side of a lake, river, or sea to the other:vượt qua
the crossing from dover to calais is often very rough.
we had a really rough crossing - i was sick three times.
the crossing was rough.

children.name: been u
children.definition: have you ever been to(= have you ever travelled to )japan?
examples: ihave been to(= have travelled to )germany several times.
